description: How can I care for her?
title: My baby has diarrhea
content:
Created by BabyCenter


If your baby has diarrhea, she needs to replace the fluids that are being lost, or she will get dehydrated. Dehydrated means that her body does not have enough water to keep going. Keep offering your breast and let her feed as often as she wants.

Do not give your baby any fruit juice, cola or sugary drinks. These drinks can make  diarrhea worse.
If your baby is younger than 6 months, she does not need any water. Breastmilk will give her all she needs.

If your baby is older than 6 months, give her small sips of cooled, boiled water between feedings. 
Take your baby to a health provider as soon as possible if:

•	she has diarrhea  for more than 1 day

•	she has dry skin or lips

•	her urine is dark yellow and she is urinating less often

•	the soft spot in her head is sunken

•	she refuses to drink, has blood in her bowel movements or has a swollen tummy

•	she vomits for more than a day, or has a fever which lasts more than a day.
